Today's #SquawkPod: Legendary investor Stanley Druckenmiller says he’ll be listening to the bond market again, now that the Fed backs away from its economic easing policies. @steveliesman breaks down Fed Chair Jay Powell’s tricky road ahead. 

LISTEN: https://t.co/YqCNUmcc6D https://t.co/TI2sQaeWsM

"I tend to think that $AAPL in the longer term will still outperform the market," says Oppenheimer & Co. Sr. Analyst Martin Yang. "But in the medium term--now is the time to be a little bit more cautious." https://t.co/6pHOMVTYOO

"Everyone, me included, would like to hear more updates on supply chain issues," says Oppenheimer & Co. Sr. Analyst Martin Yang on $AAPL. "Another key issue in my opinion is app store policies." https://t.co/wudMC5164P

"The sell programs are overrunning the buy ... it doesn't mean that stocks are bad. It just means you should be a little more prudent," says @jimcramer. "Don't  pay attention to what futures are doing. Pay attention to what you like." https://t.co/DpCYicxSe7

"We had $155B worth of inflows...our AUM was up 42% in the last year and it is being driven by strong results for our customers," says @Blackstone's Jon Gray. "We are broadening our platform." https://t.co/go2RC4GV63

"The market has been wearing beer goggles for the longest possible time. Everything looks beautiful because money was free. They just assume the Fed is going to bail them out. The strike price on the Fed put has moved significantly," says Richard Fisher. https://t.co/VgPUzGQaB8

"It was more what he didn't say ... the market really wanted clear guidance and less ambiguity," says Citi's Kristen Bitterly on Jay Powell. "For example there was no mention of gradual. There was no in-depth discussion around inflationary pressures." https://t.co/EH7D0xs6h7

"I'm a fan that the Fed has decided to tighten and step back from expanding its balance sheet and moving toward shrinking," says @Blackstone's Jon Gray. "Obviously that will create some bumps in the road, but it will also create opportunities for investors." https://t.co/pzZjn8Qo35

"EVs are only 3% of car sales now. As they become close to 50% over the next 10 years, some of these companies can be 15x their current size," says @jonmcneill. "You have to have an attractive product, you have to have an ability to produce and it has to be a quality product." https://t.co/1MKIru0SWP

"You want to own floating rate debt, shorter duration that goes up as rates go up. That's where our credit portfolio sits. You want to own hard assets," says @Blackstone's Jon Gray. "The way to get growth and value is to own companies and assets where cash flow will grow." https://t.co/ORmss1v07O
NEW: Famed investor Stanley Druckenmiller tells @JoeSquawk he will be "listening to the bond market" once again after yesterday's comments from Fed Chair Jay Powell. https://t.co/otxyDwhQG0

"We really think the climate provisions are some of the most important, and the provisions that deal with building the new infrastructure especially for rural America," says @siemensusa @siemensus_ceo Barbara Humpton on yesterday's White House meeting on Build Back Better. https://t.co/iCqUA7iPPE

"Tesla's profit at the gross margin level is twice GM and Ford's already. The gross margins are approaching 30%," says @jonmcneill on $TSLA. "At that kind of profit margin advantage, Ford and GM have to produce twice the number of cars to achieve the same cash flow." https://t.co/JwR1Kj9u3X

Today's #SquawkPod: After today's massive turnaround in the market, hear former $GS CEO @lloydblankfein talk equities, #crypto and the Fed's plan for later this week. Plus, why he says banks stocks are a good buy.

LISTEN: https://t.co/bwQfsdeI1Y https://t.co/NCbGAyRy7i

"The last half-hour of trading has been so abysmal that I think people are really beginning to fear buying anything," says @jimcramer on the futures. "It's making it so all buys seem untenable." https://t.co/oplqz4Itd0

"It's lost a lot of value, but at a point where trillions of dollars of value contributing to it and whole ecosystems growing around it...I may be skeptical but I'm also pragmatic about it," says @lloydblankfein. "I certainly want to have an oar in that water." https://t.co/xGtzyeFegN

"I don't mind taking a pause here and letting us absorb a lot of the stimulus that's already been introduced into the market ... obviously if you pump a lot of money in you're going to have inflationary effects," says @lloydblankfein on if more fiscal stimulus is needed. https://t.co/FyLludmo92

"There has to be some redistribution of it with the tax system," says @lloydblankfein. "On the other hand, I'm not for putting a greater part of the economy into the hands of the government." https://t.co/BYVOCXkh4r

"Away from any additional tailwind you get from a change in interest rates or the yield curve they're making a lot of money in this market," says @lloydblankfein on the banks. "The earnings have been there, and they trade on an unbelievably low multiple." https://t.co/aKa9CQSele

"I don't think we're watching a looming WWIII .... generally markets are kind of amoral. I don't know that it necessarily has to affect most equity prices," says @lloydblankfein on the Russia-Ukraine tensions. https://t.co/1Kv19rC3TN

"We're starting at short-term rates are 0-25 basis points. There's a lot of room to go up and equities still being the best game in town," says @lloydblankfein on why the current #inflation environment might be different from the 70s. https://t.co/fFsU6I9A3o

"There's a lot of #inflation out there. The bulk of it doesn't feel transitory. Some of it might be," says former $GS CEO @lloydblankfein. "Some of it is transitory but I'm not Pollyannish. The Fed is getting into gear here. They will probably come out and say hawkish stuff." https://t.co/mJVP1iT2pM
